fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A sequence \dots \xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i + 1}} x_i\xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i}} x_{i - 1}\xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i - 1}} \dots in a preabelian category is exact if \ker \text {d}_{i - 1} \cong \operatorname {im} \text {d}_i for each i. In particular, the sequence is a chain complex; if the category is abelian, this equivalently means its chain homology vanishes.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categories and sheaves
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{riehl-2017, title = {Categories and Sheaves}, author = {Kashiwara, Masaki and Schapira, Pierre}, isbn = {978-3-540-27950-1}, publisher = {Springer Berlin}, year = {2005}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Categories and sheaves, which emerged in the middle of the last century as an enrichment for the concepts of sets and functions, appear almost everywhere in mathematics nowadays.

This book covers categories, homological algebra and sheaves in a systematic and exhaustive manner starting from scratch, and continues with full proofs to an exposition of the most recent results in the literature, and sometimes beyond.

The authors present the general theory of categories and functors, emphasising inductive and projective limits, tensor categories, representable functors, ind-objects and localization. Then they study homological algebra including additive, abelian, triangulated categories and also unbounded derived categories using transfinite induction and accessible objects. Finally, sheaf theory as well as twisted sheaves and stacks appear in the framework of Grothendieck topologies.

fr:title.text: Monos and epis in preabelian categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monos and epis in preabelian categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given that f is a mono, and noting that the zero map z\xrightarrow {0} x equalizes f and x\xrightarrow {0} y, any other map x\to z which equalizes these maps must also be 0. The zero map factors uniquely through the object 0, so that 0 satisfies the universal property of the kernel.
The coimage is now the cokernel of the kernel, hence the cokernel of the zero map 0\to x, hence the coequalizer of the zero map with itself, hence just the identity at x.
Exactness follows from the definition of an exact sequence.

A short exact sequence 0\to x\xhookrightarrow {f} y\xtwoheadrightarrow {g} z\to 0 is an exact sequence with all but three objects zero, i.e. so that \ker g = \operatorname {im} f, \ker f = 0, and \operatorname {im} g = z.
A preabelian category is abelian if every morphism is strict, i.e. if the natural map from its coimage to its image is an isomorphism.
Let \{x_i \xrightarrow {\text {d}_i} x_{i - 1}\} be a chain complex in an abelian category A. The nth chain homology is the "quotient of the n-cycles by the n-boundaries".

Thinking of the kernel of \text {d}_n as the n-cycles and the image of \text {d}_{n + 1} as the n-boundaries, reading the cokernel as the quotient \operatorname {im}\text {d}_{n + 1} / \ker \text {d}_n explains the slogan.
The cohomology of a cochain complex is defined dually.
A preabelian category is an additive category which has all kernels and cokernels; hence is finitely complete and cocomplete.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since additive categories have biproducts, it suffices to show that kernels and cokernels give equalizers and coequalizers; the equalizer of f and g is the same as the kernel of f - g, and dually for coequalizers.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A chain complex in an additive category is a \mathbb {Z}-graded sequence of objects \{x_i\} equipped with maps x_i\xrightarrow {\text {d}_i} x_{i-1}, called differentials, so that x_{i+1}\xrightarrow {\text {d}_{i+1}}x_i\xrightarrow {\text {d}_i}x_{i-1} = 0. We often omit the index on the differentials, so that the equation asks simply \text {d}^2 = 0.
Dually, a cochain complex has differentials written in the opposite direction, i.e. so x_i\xrightarrow {\text {d}_i} x_{i+1}.
If a chain complex is graded in some connected subset of \mathbb {Z}, for instance \mathbb {N}, then it extends to a chain complex in a unique way by filling in with zero objects.
A zero object is both initial and terminal.
